Comments_List: I have a very comprehensive understanding of Middle East history and how it effects current issues in the region.

I learned an incredible amount of information in this class, ranging from the organization and successes of early Muslim empires to nationalist leaders and movements that transformed regional governments and cultures in the Middle East. We also learned a great deal about how the Middle East has influenced  and in turn, was influenced by  European/Western powers throughout history, which also helped me better understand a lot of current American foreign policy.
I learned a lot about the middle east region and by the end of the class was able to connect how it is all related/intertwined.
I learned about the Middle East from the rise of Muhammad up through the modern era, taking into account the European and American influence

This is an excellent survey of the history of the Middle East. You'll learn major themes that have shaped the region and information about key people and treaties.

Lectures were interesting and well organized, a great class! Expectations about the final and paper were a little unclear - communication could be better.

The lectures were wonderful. Prof. Foster is a wonderful storyteller who managed to unravel the complex history of the Middle East so that it was both fascinating and understandable. I liked that he was able to make compelling arguments while acknowledging alternative perspectives, as well as weaving in fun facts and personal anecdotes into his lectures. Prof. Foster was also extremely kind during office hours and very accommodating/understanding when it came to exam grades and choosing whether to write the final paper. The one main area of improvement I can identify is that I wish there was more organization/transparency to the class. The syllabus was unclear in certain places regarding dates/deadlines and expectations for the readings, exams, and final paper.

Don't get me wrong, I loved the material covered in this course, but it really needs to be improved in a variety of ways. There needs to be some type of guided notes for the lectures in digital form given before the class starts. The key terms are presented out of order from the course packet, which make them extremely hard to follow and take notes on...not to mention they differ from the terms on the board. Also, when there is no powerpoint or slides, students lose engagement in what the professor is saying, and if you miss one thing that's said, you have no way to figure it out, especially when the key terms sheet is so outdated. The only possible way to take notes was with a large group of people, and even then it was still challenging because we would have 10+ pages of notes per lecture and not know what was important because we had 2 completely different sets of key terms to study...and then on the final, there were two terms not on either list (SAVAK/Carter Doctrine). Sure we briefly discussed both in class at some point, but they weren't listed on the sheet of terms we were supposed to memorize, which I think is unfair. Finally, there needs to be better proctoring during the exams. People cheat, and it's really unfair to those of us who study like crazy and take the exam fairly. People were constantly on their phones googling during the test and people had cheat sheets/notes hidden in their sleeves/bathroom. Like I said at the beginning, I really enjoyed the material covered in this course, I just think there is a lot of room for improvement. I wouldn't make these suggestions/observations unless I truly cared about this class, which I clearly do. Thank you!

Yes, a great overview of the history of the region. I knew nothing going into the class, and feel like I could now have a strong conversation about the Middle East. I am not a history major but found the class reasonable and definitely lots of learning. Prof. Foster is a good lecturer too.

This is a great class if, like me, youre looking for an opportunity to learn about a region you know very little about. Prof. Foster combines storytelling with wonderful anecdotes and compelling arguments to make a 9am class surprisingly bearable (although 75 minutes of pure lecture was a little rough). This class covers a TON of information, from the life of Muhammad in the seventh century all the way until the present day, so you cover a lot of ground without much time for really delving into some of the more complex and nuanced forces that may have shaped the present-day Middle East. I wouldnt recommend the class if youre looking for a deeper understanding of the Middle East or are interested in a specific region, but this is a good crash course on the Middle East that has made me feel a lot more knowledgeable about the region, as well as comfortable enough to learn more on my own in the future. As far as the workload goes, the class is not too bad  there are a lot of readings, but they arent required to do well on the exams (still, I wish I had put more time into the readings, because the ones I managed to get to were interesting and super helpful with reinforcing lecture material). The hardest part was probably preparing for the exams. Although they were appropriately challenging and graded fairly, there was just so much information that cramming at the last minute didnt work. Overall, I would definitely recommend Intro to the Middle East as a survey course that provides a gateway into understanding a complex, often misrepresented region of the world.
